M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: This action arises under the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts governing residential tenancies and the covenant of quiet enjoyment, M.G.L. c. 186, §14.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19, because the premises at issue are located in Worcester County and the defendant conducts business there.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: In Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977), the Supreme Judicial Court held that a landlord is liable for interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment when the landlord’s conduct or omission substantially impairs the tenant’s beneficial use of the premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses landlord liability for breach of quiet enjoyment based on the landlord’s conduct/omission and its effect on the tenant’s use of the premises. The court holds that, even without an intent to evict, a landlord breaches the covenant where conditions that are the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done “very substantially deprived” tenants of quiet enjoyment, and it ties this to the premises being not reasonably habitable. This aligns with the proposition that liability arises when the landlord’s conduct or omission substantially impairs the tenant’s beneficial use.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: In Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982), the Court held that a landlord’s failure to alleviate water infiltration and nuisance conditions breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion does find that the landlord’s allowing repeated flooding interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment and created liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but the court ultimately vacates the $10,000 quiet-enjoyment damages award as duplicative and directs that judgment be entered for the landlord on that aspect of the case. Thus, Simon v. Solomon does not stand as a holding that the landlord’s failure to alleviate the water infiltration breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment in a way that produced a sustained, independent covenant-based recovery. It primarily affirms liability for emotional distress and habitability, and treats quiet enjoyment through the statute rather than as a freestanding common-law covenant breach supporting that proposition.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The jury found in answer to a special question… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.… In sum, we hold that a tenant need not seek a criminal conviction before claiming damages under G. L. c. 186, § 14.… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment… We… vacate the $10,000 judgment for Solomon for interference with quiet enjoyment.”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: In Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987), persistent rodent infestation constituted a breach of quiet enjoyment where the landlord failed to take effective remedial action.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion mentions the presence of mice and ants only as part of a list of various sanitary code violations and does not analyze them as a distinct issue or tie them to a breach of quiet enjoyment. The court discusses breach of warranty of habitability and rent abatement, but there is no holding or reasoning that persistent rodent infestation, coupled with a landlord’s failure to take effective remedial action, constituted a breach of quiet enjoyment. Thus, the case does not establish or affirm the specific proposition claimed.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: “The violations include the existence of lead paint, cracked windows, missing window screens, stained ceiling, loose bathroom tiles, mice, ants, missing balustrades on the porches, inadequate trash receptables, and inadequate door locks.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: In Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979), the Court emphasized that landlords must maintain premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code (see 105 C.M.R. 410.550, vermin prevention).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly grounds the landlord’s warranty of habitability duty in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and expressly states that, at a minimum, the landlord must meet sanitary and building code standards. While this case is factually about heat and hot water rather than vermin, it makes clear that the Code (including its specific provisions such as 105 C.M.R. 410.550 on vermin) defines the minimum habitability obligations that landlords must maintain. Thus, citing Berman for the general proposition that landlords must keep premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code is accurate, even if vermin is not the specific issue litigated.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In the latter instance, the landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes. Whether the scope of the warranty is broader is an open question. Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443, 451 (1979). … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969) (current version at 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.190, 410.200, 410.201). The landlord can have no reasonable grounds to believe that noncompliance will be acceptable.”

105 C.M.R. 410.550.proposition: In Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979), the Court emphasized that landlords must maintain premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code (see 105 C.M.R. 410.550, vermin prevention).

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: In Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), the SJC recognized that the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment overlap in ensuring tenants a safe, sanitary living space.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion discusses the implied warranty of habitability and, separately, the constructive eviction doctrine and statutory remedies, but it does not state that the implied warranty and the covenant of quiet enjoyment overlap in ensuring a safe, sanitary living space. The justice actually criticizes the majority’s broader warranty concept and urges tying the landlord’s obligation strictly to statutory and code minimum standards, without framing that in terms of overlap with the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Any such overlap, if discussed at all, appears in parts of the majority opinion not included in this excerpt.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “Admittedly the rule suggested above does not cover the situation constituting a ‘constructive eviction’ of a tenant which is discussed in the court’s opinion, but that is because the facts of the present cases do not involve such a situation. There is nothing to suggest that our courts which have heretofore given relief to a tenant who is the victim of a ‘constructive eviction’ will not continue to do so in an appropriate case. Historically the orderly development and evolution of the common law has been accomplished primarily by the judicial decision of issues actually in controversy…”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771 (1994) reiterated that a landlord’s failure to maintain the premises in compliance with housing codes can constitute interference under §14.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion is about the proper measure of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability in a Section 8 tenancy; the covenant of quiet enjoyment claim under G.L. c. 186, § 14 is mentioned only in passing, and no damages were awarded on that claim. The court does not discuss, analyze, or reiterate any rule that failure to comply with housing codes constitutes ‘interference’ under § 14. The proposition therefore overstates what this case holds and is not supported by this opinion.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: “Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994) affirmed that emotional distress damages may be awarded for a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and holds that the landlord may be liable for serious interference with tenants’ quiet enjoyment based on failure to act, and that tenants may obtain damages, injunctive relief, costs, and attorney’s fees. However, the court does not specifically address or authorize emotional distress damages in this case, nor does it affirm any prior holding on emotional distress damages for breach of quiet enjoyment. The case is about liability and available forms of relief generally, not about emotional distress damages in particular.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the judge erred in granting summary judgment for the defendant on the plaintiffs’ claim of violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14. There must be a trial to determine what, if any, measures the defendant has taken… If the defendant has taken no action or inadequate action… then the plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment, appropriate injunctive relief, costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. See G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

M.G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 239, §8A, a tenant may counterclaim or bring direct suit for damages arising from a landlord’s breach of lawful housing obligations.

Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Trust.raw_text: Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Trust v. Cambridge Point, LLC, 478 Mass. 697 (2018)
Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Trust.proposition: Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Trust v. Cambridge Point, LLC, 478 Mass. 697 (2018) and Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross, 388 Mass. 16 (1983) confirm that Massachusetts courts will award consequential damages for statutory violations that impair property enjoyment.

Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.raw_text: Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross, 388 Mass. 16 (1983)
Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.proposition: Trustees of Cambridge Point Condo. Trust v. Cambridge Point, LLC, 478 Mass. 697 (2018) and Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross, 388 Mass. 16 (1983) confirm that Massachusetts courts will award consequential damages for statutory violations that impair property enjoyment.
Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.case_name: Coveney v. President & Trustees of the College of the Holy Cross
Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.support_reasoning: Coveney involves a wrongful-expulsion claim against a private college and addresses whether the college acted arbitrarily or capriciously and whether a release barred suit. The opinion does not concern statutory violations, property rights, or consequential damages, nor does it discuss remedies for impaired enjoyment of property. It therefore does not provide authority for the proposition that Massachusetts courts will award consequential damages for statutory violations impairing property enjoyment.
Coveney v. President & Trustees of the C.relevant_excerpt: "We dispose of this case on the ground that the college did not violate any contractual or other rights of the plaintiffs by expelling Coveney, and on the additional ground that Coveney waived the claims he asserts here by executing a valid and binding general release.… We affirm the judgment of the Superior Court on the grounds that Coveney’s dismissal did not violate his contractual or constitutional rights and was not arbitrary or capricious."

105 C.M.R. 410.00 et seq..proposition: That the Court order Defendant to remediate all rodent infestations and bring the property into compliance with the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.00 et seq.; and
